https://prez.dev/description.@value: The point or level from which heights and depths are measured and referenced to for an entity or activity. Typically these are expressed relative to a common global or regional reference datum such as the Australian Height Datum (AHD) or can be related to local reference systems. Specific emphasis is placed on elevation references used by resource exploration and drilling programs, whereby depths are measured relative to local reference datums or specific parts of a borehole/drilling platform. Concepts in this vocabulary include both reference datums (e.g. mean sea level) and how depths are expressed relative to them (e.g. mean sea level height).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) is a reference surface for heights in Australia, introduced on 1 January 2020 to allow more accurate height computations where needed. Due to biases and distortions of the AHD, Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) users are only capable of deriving AHD heights with accuracy of 6–13 cm across Australia, which is inappropriate for some applications that require a more accurate reference surface. AVWS heights can be computed directly from GNSS without needing to connect to survey mark infrastructure with accuracy of 4–8 cm. AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining, whereas the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy and hydrography.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Based on the recommendation of the 'https://www.icsm.gov.au/publications/australian-vertical-working-surface-technical-implementation-plan-v16' study to adopt a 'two-frame' approach similar to that done with GDA2020 and Australian Terrestrial Reference Frame.

AVWS heights can be computed directly from GNSS without needing to connect to survey mark infrastructure with accuracy of 4–8 cm. AHD is considered fit for purpose for tasks over short distances (less than about 10 km) for projects such as cadastral, civil engineering, construction and mining, whereas the Australian Vertical Working Surface (AVWS) has been defined to assist users working over larger areas (greater than about 10 km) for environmental studies (e.g. flood, storm modelling), LiDAR surveys, geodesy and hydrography.
